follow https://gist.github.com/robertpainsi/b632364184e70900af4ab688decf6f53 for commit message guidelines.

As will mentioned, please take a look at commit message guidelines.  This is also a good reference: https://cbea.ms/git-commit/

In general we don't want to see a "history" of a single change in the commit message.  Gerrit allows us to see the difference between revisions.  Once the commit is merged we don't care about that history anymore, so it doesn't belong in the commit message.

To be explicit there shouldn't be anything in the commit message along the lines of "fixed up review comments from previous revision".

Thanks Patrick.

Yes, that reference was what I was trying to find, but failed to find it.
I have fixed the commit message 😊

Hi everyone,

Thanks for the fast review! I made some new changes according to your suggestions, and don't mind the patchset #, I was just re-learning my git commands.

It would be great if everyone could give another round of reviews to my latest commit.

Thanks,

Simon

I get the impression this document really isn't targeted at the OpenBMC community.  It is worded like an internal Google design document.  Is this really intended for Google consumption only?  If not, can you elaborate how someone outside Google would gain utility from this?
I don't know what this means.  All the metadata is in github.com/openbmc/openbmc .  What additional metadata are vendors installing?

Patrick, I agree this doc needs some reword: the information that is Google specific need to be removed. Thanks for your feedback.

The main idea of this design is to introduce Google Cloud Build (GCB) as an alternative to Jenkins. It's much like the previous k8s configs and scripts (today they are removed since no one maintains int). Everyone in the community can use these configs and scripts, which we will contribute to the openbmc_build_scripts repo, to set up GCB for their platform.

GCB supports many features that current Jenkins based system supports:
1. continuously release
2. presubmit and put labels as feedbacks
I have implemented Nan's suggestion to the proposal. It is now addressed to the OpenBMC community.
Simon, please note that the benefit of this project to Google and OpenBMC community is different. This might confuse upstream reviewers. See my above comment.
Done
You seem to be discussing "releases", between you (Google) and your ODMs.  I don't know how that is related to CI which is the title of this design.
Right, I have removed this part as it does not relate to this proposal.
How is access to Google's internal git repositories applicable to the open source community?
This shall be replaced by OpenBMC Gerrit.
Done!

We already have this Dockerfile.

https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc-build-scripts/blob/master/build-setup.sh
Right, to support GCB's configuration syntax, we might need to separate the Dockerfile part from the build script and add some new dependencies.
I needed to add a few python dependencies to make our scripts work.

Simon, this is good start. But I encourage you do some reword for the entire proposal.

Upstream design is not converting your internal intern proposal to a different format. Internally, yes, it's for vendors and the current content is relevant. However, introducing GCB to OpenBMC is not for Google vendors, it's for the community. It's providing an alternative to the current Jenkins based OpenBMC CI system. 

Think about the following questions, and write them explicitly in the doc,

1. What's the real problem we want solve? hint: we are working on **CI**.

2. What does current OpenBMC CI consist of? what features does it support? hint: OpenBMC Ci is based on Jenkins.

3. Why GCB? Is it providing the supported features that current OpenBMC CI Infra provides? Is GCB better? hint: you can research on how GCB advertises itself.

4. Why is Google hiring an intern to do this? How does getting codes into upstream help Google? hint: Google vendors can contribute codes directly; and think about why open source helps. 

5. What does Yocto based firmware builds require; how is that different on OpenBMC from Google internal builds? hint: read Yocto's document and understand what the repo you cloned really means.

On second thought, we should look more into on how this is a alternative to Jenkins. In a sense, it means that there need a way to support the hook from gerrit reviews to GCB (I am guessing that is supported easily). https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/wiki/Continuous-Integration. I would say that is out of scope of this.

but if we want to say that this is for OpenBMC CI, we need to be able to support that.

If not, this is just a way for people to create OpenBMC releases which allow on-demand releases.
GCB supports Github triggers. I haven't investigated how GCB works with upstream Gerrit yet. But yeah, presubmit isn't scoped in this intern project. Only on-demand releases are scoped.

I have addressed some of your points Nan. Those are all very helpful thank you very much.

1), 3) and 4) have been addressed in my latest patchset

Instead, add how this alternative benefit both OpenBMC and Google

Yeah, will do, I guess this relates to your point 4). Making this project Open Source will provide an alternative to the openBMC community, will solve our own Google internal needs and will provide better support on any bugs that we have.
There must be alternatives, right? The current Jenkins is one, what about other Cloud providers, Azure, AWS. What are their equivalent services?
That's a good point, I'll do some more research on other cloud service providers

What are the impacts? Where do we plan to submit codes to?

Overall, I reviewed this, and while I left a ton of comments, I'm not convinced the design doc process is the right one for something like this.  I suspect that a design doc approval alone won't be enough to allow or disallow cloudbuild into the project, and its inclusion into openbmc-build-scripts is going to depend heavily on:
1. How invasive the code changes it needs to make are.
2. If the maintainers are willing to maintain it (and if not, if he's willing to let someone else maintain a portion of the build scripts that contain gcb).
3. If the measured impacts to the obvious performance metrics (build time, SLA ect) are compelling enough to be worth the cost of the switch.
4. If the "Open" part of openbmc can be maintained, while still allowing gcb support.

As an experiment, and line of engineering, this sounds very interesting, and something that's worth pursuing.  I don't think any of the maintainers can answer any of the above questions without seeing a series of patchsets, so my recommendation would be to start working.  Try to determine the refactorings and cleanups that need to happen that are irrelevant to enabling cloudbuild, and get those pushed first in your series, then get a basic prototype working, and we can evaluate the above from there.


Overall, I think having more options for heterogeneity in build-server use is a good thing, not bad, and we should encourage it to the point that the complexity and maintainability will allow it.

One thing that isn't made clear in this design doc, but should be;  At this point Google has no plans that I'm aware of for removing the non-gcb Jenkins CI resources that we currently donate to the project.  If gcb turns out to be a compelling option for any of the important metrics, there's an obvious path for us to convert how we donate to the project in the form of gcb resources instead of direct compute, but that will be a much bigger discussion, and has to encompass the best needs for the project.


Overall, good stuff, lets see some good results.

Hello Ed, thanks a lot for your detailed review. I would like Simon to answer most of your questions. 

I can provide some high level context: this is a 3-month intern project, and what is scoped is providing an alternative CI for "on demand BMC releases" only. The main target users for Google are Google's vendors. It's unlikely we will replace Jenkins in this time period. Instead, if we can finish the GCB configuration, get an E2E workflow demoed, push PRs to openbmc-build-scripts, and get them reviewed at the end of the internship, that's a solid start of the upstream GCB story, and it also fulfills our internal use cases. Google team and vendors will maintain the contributed codes.

> The main target users for Google are Google's vendors. 

Then this doesn't really need an upstream design doc if we're not planning on doing this work upstream or reporting status back to upstream.

Like I said, it seems a bit awkward to be dealing with an upstream design doc, especially so given the scope that you just laid out.  This is a super interesting line of research, and we should keep looking into it, but I think discord is probably a better forum for talking about individual changes, given that nobody on this doc is going to be able to approve that level of scope, so I would get on the #infrastruture channel, and start sending PRs for the things you need to do, and you can talk with the CI maintainers there when individual things come up that you'd like to refactor in openbmc-build-scripts.  I suspect the abstraction of the separation is going to be important in those discussions.


> push PRs to openbmc-build-scripts, and get them reviewed at the end of the internship,

I'm sure you know this, but it's worth reiterating, don't push all your reviews at the end of the internship.  Make incremental progress over time in a series of patchsets submitted as you work, keeping the maintainers in the loop.  That will get you the best result.

Thanks for the comments Ed. I have been lurking around the infrastructure channel on discord. Are you suggesting that I start pushing my code internally so that I can get reviews from Nan and Willy, whilst taking suggestion from the discord?

No, I mean what I said above:

> Try to determine the refactorings and cleanups that need to happen that are irrelevant to enabling cloudbuild, and get those pushed first in your series, then get a basic prototype working, and we can evaluate the above from there.
The basic prototype works, I will have a demo ready on March 8th. I can record a demo and show it
Nit, try to avoid using possessive adjectives like this.  Just call it OpenBMC;  Whether it's ours, yours, or mine is immaterial.
Sounds good :)

Please follow the Openbmc template for this stuff, which should go in the background and references section.  Also, I realize that these are mostly googlable, but please add some crosslinks.

https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/designs/design-template.md
Thanks I will look into this
Lets add some more detail here.  "scaling" and "availability" have a lot of different definitions, so lets be crystal clear about what we're hoping to solve here.
Sounds good. Thanks Ed

In terms of defintions, this is not part of the problem description.  This second paragraph is jumping directly to "gcp is great because".  Lets move the "gcp is great" stuff to the proposed design section.
Good point I'll change that
For which builds?  There's a dozen or so build types specified.  Lets focus on the most common build types (repository and full build) and call out our targets by name.
Right, I've made this requirement more specific.

This should not be a requirement.  The user should not get to select their build type.  Either sstate-cache works as designed, automatically, and this setting isn't required, or it doesn't and this setting would be set by the administrator.

If user == administrator, lets be precise about that.
Right, that's something we can set in the code itself.

This needs some more details on what this requirement means.  I think what we're really getting at here is that GCB should scale up and down based on the needs of the project with a reasonable level of ease.

Yeah, I'll more detail about this part.

Edit: user can select which machine type they would like.

Same as above, using "our own" doesn't convey whos the owner, which we should be explicit about.  Is it google? openbmc (ie linux foundation)?


Also, this as written isn't a requirement.  It's part of the design.
The machines in questions are the VM executors that Google Cloud build uses. So it would be gcb machines or gcp machines

Some other important requirements:
1. Builds should not rely on non-public components of the gcb infrastructure.
2. Builds should be capable of completely replacing jenkins, and support all build types.
3. Builds should be capable of "garbage collecting" with jenkins-equivalent or better rules for which builds to keep, and which builds to remove.
4. Builds should be able to operate without administrator gerrit credentials, and when running without them, should avoid actions that require credentials (ie, setting build verify flags, ect).
5. Artifacts from the build system are made available the public through appropriate linking
6. System must be capable of setting the Verified status on gerrit patches.
7. System should be maintainable, and should be the minimal set of diffs against existing openbmc to attain the design goals.  This is a super fuzzy requirement, but I suspect for something like this to be viable, it can't be reinventing and bifurcating all the existing capabilities we have.
Those are all important requirements. I will look more deeply into those and think of more
I've went through all these requirements. Some I don't understand but for the ones that I do, I have expanded on them.
Done

This is great that you have milestones, but this isn't really what a design section is about.  Design should cover HOW you're planning on doing it, although, based on my reading, can probably be pretty minimal, because 90% of it is going to be "use gcb to execute build jobs", it's not clear there's a lot to design at this level.
Right, will remove the milestones.

Nit, the python version is unimportant at this level of document.  If the implementation requires python 3.2, that's probably workable, and isn't a core piece of the design itself. yes, please use the latest python version, it's just not important.
Sounds good, I'll omit some low level details
What does this mean?  At OpenBMC project level, we don't have vendors;  Maybe this is a missing requirement around being able to use this on non-upstream repositories?
Right, this is unrelated to OpenBMC.
"should" type vernacular implies this is also a requirement, not a design, and should go in the requirements section.
You're right, this should go in the requirements section thanks Ed
while this is good, I suspect there aren't great mocks for calling GCP resources, so I would classify this as a nice to have.
Yeah absolutely right, I will mention that unit tests will only be utilized in development and not included in the actual release.
Nit, this is OpenBMC, and we should follow its rules (which admittedly, I'm pretty sure are a subset of the Google python style guide).
Yeah, I'm pretty sure PEP 8 is sufficient enough.
What does this mean?
Right, this document should make sense to the general public. I have added some more details to this portion.
What does "branch support" mean?
Yeah it's a bit unclear, but what I'm trying to say is the ability to specify which branches we git clone from in the initial yaml config file.
If our goal is to push this to upstream, this seems like a non-starter for a public project.  Maybe the visibility is configurable, but anything we ran for the main project would need to be public.
Right, I guess it should be that it needs to be accessible by the public. The artifacts would be stored on GCS, and we would need to make it downloadable or something to the public.
This would be a great piece in your design section.  The "impacts" section is "here's the things that are going to be potential problems"
Thanks, I'll move it to the appropriate section

Upgrade implies a complete replacement, which I don't think is a goal here?


One missing impact is that there will be two code paths to maintain and test.  You should mention that, as well as ways you plan to mitigate that impact to the project.

Yeah, should probably remove upgrade.

You're right that introducing more complexity is a problem.
Why didn't you pick these?  More details.

While I'm not entirely sure, I believe that Google's goals are to create a CI for its vendors, it'll be "cheaper" to use Google tools to achieve that goal. Thus it makes sense to use our own tools rather than other companies tools. If all of them have similar performance, then using GCB makes sense.

> While I'm not entirely sure, I believe that Google's goals are to create a CI for its vendors, it'll be "cheaper" to use Google tools to achieve that goal. Thus it makes sense to use our own tools rather than other companies tools. If all of them have similar performance, then using GCB makes sense.

Remember, this is an upstream design doc, there is no "our tools", but it'd be easy enough to phrase something like:
"Because of Googles participation in the OpenBMC project, donation of gcb resources is a lot more available than X"


> If all of them have similar performance, then using GCB makes sense.

I suspect that even if azure was faster here (which I don't think it is) we still wouldn't likely use it.
Thanks for the suggestion Ed, I'll make sure to say something similar as to what you have suggested.
Done
I added an explanation along the lines of what you said Ed.
Performance tests?  Tests to ensure that it generates the same binaries as before?  Tests to ensure that CI failures are caught?  Tests to ensure gerrit integration is working?

Testing for binaries is very important. So I guess we need to test multiple builds on GCB to ensure that the binaries are consistent across different builds.

For sure CI failures will need to be caught. There is basic failure handling right now with the current project, but clearly terminating and indicating CI failure will be extremely important
All the above is what the testing section is for.
Done
Done

Hello everyone,

I have fixed up the proposal a lot by implementing everyone's suggestions. Thank you very much for pointing me in the right direction, this is my first time working on an open-source project.

There are still some comments that I have not implemented yet, but a lot of the content has been improved.

Please take a look 😊

Thanks,

Simon

> There are still some comments that I have not implemented yet

This is a bit of an anti-pattern to request reviews when you're still reworking things.  It requires that reviewers double-review (ie, review the half-done one, and then review when you've made all the changes to make it complete)
Thanks for letting me know. I wanted to give some progress, I'll add the rest of the changes today.
Changes have been added in the latest patchset

> Patch Set 13:
> 
> (42 comments)
> 
> This change is ready for review.

I'm going to reiterate here..... I don't see how this review can get merged by upstream maintainers in the timeframe you're looking for.  There's too many technical questions unanswered to say whether or not this kind of design would be accepted, and those questions would largely only be answered by patchsets showing utility and abstractions in backing resources, not design docs.

I also just realized that the CI maintainer (Geissler) wasn't even CCed on this review;  Considering that he's the one that would likely be approving any code-level changes to ci or openbmc-build-scripts, it seems important that he is included in the design.

Thanks Ed, the intention is not merge this review during my internship. Rather, I'd like to push for some additional discussions as much as possible. I only have around 1.5 months left in my internship, so yes that timeframe is unrealistic, but I hope I can progress this review a lot further 😊

I don't have much to add here that hasn't already been said. Small commits proving the value is probably the best option at this point.

I'm having a lot of flashbacks to when IBM had an intern get Kubernetes working with CI. https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/openbmc-build-scripts/+/41302 was the final result of that experiment :(  It really needs to be something that is easy to maintain AND shows a significant improvement in some way over what we already have.
Thanks for the comment Andrew. When you mean by small commits, do you mean code commits?

Hi Andrew, is there a place where I can upload my codes to? I am ready to push some codes and hopefully we'll see some more improvements :)

Thanks,

Simon
You need to push your code for review to the openbmc/openbmc-build-scripts repository here in Gerrit.
